dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: This Saudi price war with Russia, I just don't see it having such a massive global impact. Markets are always been volatile.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: This Saudi price war with Russia, I just don't see it having such a massive global impact. Markets are always been volatile.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Global stocks plunged after crude oil posted its biggest fall since the 1991 Gulf War after Saudi Arabia launched a price war with Russia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the numbers are staggering, like Japan's Nikkei fell over 5% in a single day. That's not just normal volatility.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the numbers are staggering, like Japan's Nikkei fell over five percent in a single day. That's not just normal volatility.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Japans Nikkei index fell more than 5% on Monday, while stocks in Hong Kong and mainland China were also down as panicked investors in Asia flocked to safe-haven assets like government bonds and the Japanese yen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but markets bounce back all the time. It's just a temporary panic, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but markets bounce back all the time. It's just a temporary panic, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, not when you see the ASX in Australia lost 92 billion dollars in value. That's its worst since the financial crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, not when you see the A S X in Australia lost ninety two billion dollars in value. That's its worst since the financial crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some $90 billion ($140 billion AUD) was wiped off Australias markets on Monday, with the benchmark ASX falling more than 7%its worst performance since the global financial crash.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, that is a huge number. But what about the Fed's rate cut on March 4th? Shouldn't that help stabilize things?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, that is a huge number. But what about the Fed's rate cut on March fourth? Shouldn't that help stabilize things?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves emergency rate on March 3, 2020, provided a momentary confidence boost for the markets, which now will look for coordinated action from the G7 club of advanced economies to underpin the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it did for a moment, but now with oil prices collapsing—Brent crude at $33 a barrel—it's like a perfect storm with the coronavirus fears.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it did for a moment, but now with oil prices collapsing-Brent crude at thirty three dollars a barrel-it's like a perfect storm with the coronavirus fears.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oil prices plummeted with the benchmark Brent crude down to $33.20 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate fell 31%, to $28.32 a barrel on Sunday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You think the oil drop is that significant? I mean, cheaper oil should be good for some economies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You think the oil drop is that significant? I mean, cheaper oil should be good for some economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Not when it's this sudden. Goldman Sachs is warning it could go as low as $19 if the price war keeps up. That's gonna hurt producers and spook investors even more.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not when it's this sudden. Goldman Sachs is warning it could go as low as nineteen dollars if the price war keeps up. That's gonna hurt producers and spook investors even more.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oil prices could drop to a low of $20 a barrel, Goldman Sachs analysts warned on Sunday, if the coronavirus continues to spread and the oil price war intensifies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, so you're saying it's the combination of the virus and the oil shock that's driving this sell-off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, so you're saying it's the combination of the virus and the oil shock that's driving this sell-off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Global markets have posted some of their steepest falls since the 2008-2011 financial crisis with panicked moves from investors spooked by the potential impact of the coronavirus on the global economy, and an oil price war.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And now Europe's following—FTSE down almost 8%, France over 7%. It's just spreading.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And now Europe's following-F T S E down almost eight percent, France over seven percent. It's just spreading.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: European stocks followed suit, with Londons FTSE 100 index down almost 8% on Monday morning, Frances CAC 40 more than 7% and Germanys DAX 6%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And U.S. futures are down sharply too, right? S&P futures dropped more than 5%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And U.S. futures are down sharply too, right? S&P futures dropped more than five percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. futures were sharply down, with S&P 500 futures down more than 5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and with Italy becoming a major hotspot for Covid-19, quarantines are gonna further disrupt global supply chains.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and with Italy becoming a major hotspot for Covidminus nineteen, quarantines are gonna further disrupt global supply chains.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some 110,000 people globally have been infected with Covid-19 to date, but as of Monday the number of new cases in China, where the pneumonia-like virus was detected, appear to be falling, while cases around the world continue to prompt strict quarantine measures, particularly in Italy, now the largest cluster of Covid-19-related deaths outside China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So what's next? Are we looking at coordinated action from the G7 or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what's next? Are we looking at coordinated action from the G7 or something?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves emergency rate on March 3, 2020, provided a momentary confidence boost for the markets, which now will look for coordinated action from the G7 club of advanced economies to underpin the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Probably, but until then, investors are just fleeing to safe havens like government bonds. It's gonna be a rough ride.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Probably, but until then, investors are just fleeing to safe havens like government bonds. It's gonna be a rough ride.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Japans Nikkei index fell more than 5% on Monday, while stocks in Hong Kong and mainland China were also down as panicked investors in Asia flocked to safe-haven assets like government bonds and the Japanese yen.

artist_script:
HostA: This Saudi price war with Russia, I just don't see it having such a massive global impact. Markets are always been volatile.
HostB: But the numbers are staggering, like Japan's Nikkei fell over 5% in a single day. That's not just normal volatility.
HostA: Okay, but markets bounce back all the time. It's just a temporary panic, right?
HostB: Uh, not when you see the ASX in Australia lost 92 billion dollars in value. That's its worst since the financial crisis.
HostA: Alright, that is a huge number. But what about the Fed's rate cut on March 4th? Shouldn't that help stabilize things?
HostB: Well, it did for a moment, but now with oil prices collapsing—Brent crude at $33 a barrel—it's like a perfect storm with the coronavirus fears.
HostA: You think the oil drop is that significant? I mean, cheaper oil should be good for some economies.
HostB: Not when it's this sudden. Goldman Sachs is warning it could go as low as $19 if the price war keeps up. That’s gonna hurt producers and spook investors even more.
HostA: Hmm, so you're saying it's the combination of the virus and the oil shock that's driving this sell-off.
HostB: Exactly. And now Europe's following—FTSE down almost 8%, France over 7%. It's just spreading.
HostA: And U.S. futures are down sharply too, right? S&P futures dropped more than 5%.
HostB: Yeah, and with Italy becoming a major hotspot for Covid-19, quarantines are gonna further disrupt global supply chains.
HostA: So what's next? Are we looking at coordinated action from the G7 or something?
HostB: Probably, but until then, investors are just fleeing to safe havens like government bonds. It's gonna be a rough ride.
